ground_truth: In a dimly lit room cluttered with disorder, with candlelight flickering and Leopold's portrait watching, papers cover the table, dirty dishes stack in the fireplace, and Mozart's Masonic apron lies on the forte-piano. Standing beside Constanze, who is asleep and worn out, an ill-looking Mozart approaches his sleeping son Karl, tenderly adjusting the child's blanket and resting his head beside him. Constanze awakens to see him, and Mozart rises, returning to their shared space. Suddenly, he gleefully dances alone, gesturing rudely at his father's portrait, reverting for a moment to childlike joy, until a gentle knock on the door interrupts him. As the music fades, Mozart opens the door to a masked stranger, turns to indicate Constanze, and Salieri observes them both before departing down the stairs, leaving Mozart to shut the door and close his eyes in fear, avoiding Constanze's tearful gaze. A sharp scream from Madame Weber transitions into the Queen of the Night's aria from The Magic Flute, revealing a fantastically dressed Queen urging her daughter on stage, as a captivated audience of German citizens watches in the rearranged theatre from which Schikaneder later arrives at Salieri's door, still in bird make-up with three actresses as attendants in The Magic Flute. Salieri empties a bag of coins in front of a shocked Mozart, then begins to write the key signature, guiding the composition by humming and conducting the bass vocal line.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit chamber cluttered with chaos, with candlelight flickering and Leopold's portrait observing, documents cover the table, dirty dishes pile in the hearth, and Mozart's Masonic apron lies on the fortepiano. Standing beside Constanze, who is dozing and fatigued, an ailing Mozart approaches his slumbering son Karl, tenderly adjusting the child's coverlet and resting his head beside him. Constanze awakens to see him, and Mozart rises, returning to their shared area. Suddenly, he gleefully dances alone, gesturing rudely at his father's likeness, reverting for a moment to childlike delight, until a gentle rap on the door interrupts him. As the melody fades, Mozart opens the door to a veiled stranger, turns to indicate Constanze, and Salieri observes them both before departing down the stairs, leaving Mozart to shut the door and close his eyes in dread, avoiding Constanze's tearful look. A sharp shriek from Madame Weber transitions into the Queen of the Night's aria from The Magic Flute, revealing a fantastically attired Queen urging her daughter on stage, as a captivated audience of German citizens watches in the rearranged theatre from which Schikaneder later arrives at Salieri's door, still in avian make-up with three actresses as attendants in The Magic Flute. Salieri empties a purse of coins in front of a stunned Mozart, then begins to inscribe the key signature, guiding the composition by humming and conducting the bass vocal line.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit room cluttered with disorder, with candlelight flickering and Leopold's portrait watching, the table is covered by papers, and dirty dishes are stacked in the fireplace. Mozart's Masonic apron lies on the forte-piano. Constanze, who is asleep and worn out, is stood beside by an ill-looking Mozart. He approaches his sleeping son Karl, and the child's blanket is tenderly adjusted by him as he rests his head beside him. Constanze awakens to see him, and Mozart rises, and their shared space is returned to by him. Suddenly, he is seen gleefully dancing alone, and rude gestures are made by him at his father's portrait, allowing him to revert for a moment to childlike joy, until he is interrupted by a gentle knock on the door. As the music fades, the door is opened by Mozart to reveal a masked stranger. He turns to indicate Constanze, and they are observed by Salieri before he departs down the stairs, and the door is shut by Mozart, who closes his eyes in fear, avoiding the tearful gaze of Constanze. A sharp scream from Madame Weber transitions into the Queen of the Night's aria from The Magic Flute, revealing a fantastically dressed Queen urging her daughter on stage. A captivated audience of German citizens watches in the rearranged theatre, from which Schikaneder later arrives at Salieri's door, still in bird make-up, with three actresses as attendants in The Magic Flute. A bag of coins is emptied by Salieri in front of a shocked Mozart, then he begins writing the key signature, guiding the composition by humming and conducting the bass vocal line.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit, cluttered room with flickering candlelight and Leopold's portrait, papers scatter the table, dirty dishes pile in the fireplace, and Mozart's Masonic apron is on the forte-piano. Beside a sleeping, exhausted Constanze, a sickly Mozart adjusts his son Karl's blanket and rests beside him. As Constanze awakens, Mozart rises and joyfully dances alone, rudely gesturing at his father's portrait in childlike bliss until a gentle knock interrupts him. Opening the door to a masked stranger, Mozart gestures to Constanze while Salieri observes and departs, leaving Mozart to shut the door, closing his eyes in fear to avoid Constanze's tearful look. A sharp scream from Madame Weber leads into the Queen of the Night's aria from The Magic Flute, featuring a fantastically dressed Queen urging her daughter on stage, as German citizens watch in the adjusted theatre. Schikaneder later arrives at Salieri's door, still in bird costume, with actresses from The Magic Flute. Salieri pours coins in front of a stunned Mozart, then starts writing the key signature, guiding the composition by humming and conducting the bass line.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit, cluttered room, candlelight flickers as Leopold's portrait watches. Papers cover the table, dishes stack in the fireplace, and Mozart's Masonic apron lies on the forte-piano. Beside a tired, sleeping Constanze, an ill Mozart tenderly adjusts his son Karl's blanket. Constanze wakes, and Mozart joyfully dances alone, taunting his father's portrait until interrupted by a knock. He opens the door to a masked stranger, gestures at Constanze, and Salieri observes them before leaving. Mozart shuts the door, fearing Constanzeâ€™s tearful gaze. Madame Weber's scream transitions to the Queen of the Night's aria from The Magic Flute, where the Queen urges her daughter on stage before a German audience. Schikaneder arrives at Salieri's door in bird make-up, attended by three actresses, while Salieri empties coins before a shocked Mozart, guiding the composition by humming and conducting the bass line.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: In a room filled with dim lighting and an overwhelming sense of disorder, the only illumination comes from the flickering candlelight. This setting casts a haunting glow over the space, while a portrait of Leopold thoughtfully observes the scene. The table is completely covered in scattered papers, and the fireplace is cluttered with stacks of dirty dishes, adding to the chaotic atmosphere. Mozart's Masonic apron is casually draped over the forte-piano, an artifact of his personal history and mystery. Standing beside Constanze, who is sleeping and visibly exhausted, a frail and unwell-looking Mozart approaches his slumbering son, Karl. With gentle care, he lovingly adjusts Karl's blanket and rests his head tenderly beside his son. As Constanze awakens, she notices him, prompting Mozart to rise and return to the space they share. Suddenly, in a rare moment of pure happiness, he begins to dance joyfully by himself, playfully gesturing with disrespect at his father's portrait, momentarily reverting to a state of childlike whimsy. However, this brief interlude is interrupted by a soft, unexpected knock at the door. As the ambient music fades away, Mozart opens the door to reveal a stranger wearing a mask. He then turns, pointing towards Constanze. In the shadows, Salieri observes the interaction and, without a word, quietly leaves, descending the stairs. This leaves Mozart to close the door with a sense of trepidation, closing his eyes in palpable fear, avoiding the tearful gaze of Constanze. The silence is shattered by a piercing scream from Madame Weber, seamlessly transitioning into the powerful aria of the Queen of the Night from The Magic Flute. This reveals a theatrical scene where a queen in fantastical costume is urging her daughter on stage, captivating an audience filled with German citizens in the rearranged theatre. Schikaneder, still adorned in his bird make-up, arrives at Salieri's door accompanied by three actresses, all playing attendants in The Magic Flute. In a dramatic gesture, Salieri empties a bag filled with coins in front of a stunned and speechless Mozart. He then begins composing the music, meticulously writing the key signature while guiding the process by humming and conducting the bass vocal line with precision and authority.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
In a room steeped in dim lighting and enveloped by an overwhelming sense of disarray, the only source of illumination is the wavering, flickering light of a candle. This creates an ethereal and haunting glow that casts mysterious shadows throughout the space, while a portrait of Leopold, positioned thoughtfully on the wall, seems to observe the unfolding scene with a watchful eye. The table within this setting is entirely covered with scattered papers, a chaotic jumble of documents, while the fireplace is burdened with stacks of dirty dishes, further contributing to the atmosphere of disorder and neglect. Among this clutter, Mozart's Masonic apron is casually draped over the forte-piano, an evocative artifact of his personal history and the enigmatic secrets it holds.

Beside Constanze, who is sound asleep and appears visibly exhausted, Mozart, looking frail and unwell, approaches his slumbering son, Karl, with a sense of tender care. With gentle hands, he adjusts Karl's blanket lovingly and rests his weary head tenderly beside his son's, a moment filled with paternal affection. As Constanze awakens, she becomes aware of his presence, prompting Mozart to rise from his position and return to the shared space. Suddenly, in an unusual moment of pure joy, he begins to dance exuberantly by himself. In this fleeting episode of happiness, he playfully gestures with irreverence at his father's portrait, momentarily transforming into a state of childlike whimsy and abandon. However, this brief interlude of joy is abruptly interrupted by the soft and unexpected sound of a knock at the door. As the ambient music fades, Mozart opens the door to reveal a mysterious stranger wearing a mask. He then turns his attention, pointing in the direction of Constanze. Hidden in the shadows, Salieri observes the interaction carefully and, without uttering a word, quietly departs, making his descent down the stairs. This departure leaves Mozart to close the door with a palpable sense of trepidation, closing his eyes in visible fear, and avoiding the tearful gaze of Constanze.

The silence that follows is suddenly shattered by a piercing scream from Madame Weber, seamlessly transitioning into the powerful, soaring aria of the Queen of the Night from The Magic Flute. This unveils a theatrical scene where a queen, dressed in fantastical, elaborate costume, urges her daughter on stage, captivating an audience filled with German citizens who have gathered in the rearranged theatre. Schikaneder, still adorned in his vibrant bird make-up, arrives at Salieri's door, accompanied by three actresses who play the attendants in The Magic Flute. In a dramatic flourish, Salieri empties a bag brimming with coins in front of a stunned and speechless Mozart. He then proceeds to compose the music, meticulously writing the key signature while guiding the creative process with precision, authority, and a deep sense of musical mastery, humming and conducting the bass vocal line with expert care.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit room, where disorder reigns amidst a clutter of items, the gentle flicker of candlelight casts shadows, while Leopold's portrait looms above the scene. Papers are scattered haphazardly over the table, and a pile of dirty dishes spills over the confines of the fireplace. Atop the forte-piano, Mozart's Masonic apron lies as if forgotten. Amidst this scene, an ill-looking Mozart stands next to Constanze, who lies asleep, exhausted from the day's trials. Quietly, he approaches his sleeping son Karl, carefully ensuring the blanket covers him snugly and affectionately rests his head beside the child's. Constanze stirs from her slumber, noticing Mozart's tender gesture, prompting Mozart to straighten up and retreat to the shared space they inhabit. In a sudden burst of energy, Mozart begins to dance with glee, moving exuberantly and making rude gestures towards his fatherâ€™s portrait, embodying a fleeting return to childhood innocence and mischief. This moment of joy is abruptly interrupted by a gentle tapping on the door. As the music gradually diminishes, Mozart cautiously moves to open the door, revealing a masked figure standing on the threshold. He silently gestures towards Constanze, drawing attention to her presence. Salieri, who is observing the scene, gazes upon both figures before turning away and descending the stairs, leaving Mozart to close the door behind him. As he shuts the door, a sense of dread overcomes him, and he closes his eyes, unwilling to meet Constanze's tear-filled gaze. Suddenly, a piercing scream from Madame Weber shatters the silence, seamlessly transitioning into the powerful aria of the Queen of the Night from The Magic Flute. In this fantastical moment, a Queen, resplendently dressed, fervently urges her daughter onward on the stage. The theatre, filled with the captivated faces of German citizens, watches in rapt attention. In this reconfigured theatrical setting, Schikaneder, bedecked in bird make-up and accompanied by three actresses in their respective roles from The Magic Flute, later arrives at Salieri's door. There, Salieri, confronting a visibly shocked Mozart, emphatically empties a bag of coins before him, taking up his pen to inscribe the key signature on a new page. Salieri then guides the nascent composition forward, softly humming and conducting the bass vocal line with precise, measured motions.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit and cluttered room, with candlelight flickering and Leopold's portrait overseeing the chaosâ€”papers scattered, dirty dishes in the fireplace, and Mozart's Masonic apron draped over the forte-pianoâ€”an ill-looking Mozart tenderly adjusts his sleeping son Karl's blanket before resting his head beside him. Constanze, asleep and worn out, awakens to find Mozart rising and returning to their space, where he briefly dances with childlike joy, gesturing playfully at his father's portrait. His whimsy is interrupted by a gentle knock, leading him to open the door to a masked stranger. Mozart indicates Constanze as Salieri observes them quietly before departing, leaving Mozart to close the door with fear, avoiding Constanze's tearful gaze. A sharp scream from Madame Weber transitions into the passionate Queen of the Night's aria from The Magic Flute, with a fantastically dressed Queen urging her daughter onstage, enthralling an audience of German citizens. Later, Schikaneder, clad in bird makeup, arrives with three actresses at Salieri's door. Salieri then empties a bag of coins before a shocked Mozart and begins guiding the composition by writing the key signature, humming, and conducting the bass vocal line.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit room cluttered with disorder, reminiscent of the untidy conditions that often accompanied creative genius, with candlelight flickering and Leopold's portrait watching, which served as a constant reminder of his father's expectations and legacy, papers cover the table, dirty dishes stack in the fireplace, and Mozart's Masonic apron, a symbol of his membership in the Freemasons, lies on the forte-piano. Standing beside Constanze, who, due to the strains of caring for a troubled genius, is asleep and worn out, an ill-looking Mozart approaches his sleeping son Karl, tenderly adjusting the child's blanket and resting his head beside him. Constanze awakens to see him, and Mozart rises, returning to their shared space that reflected both their love and struggles. Suddenly, he gleefully dances alone, gesturing rudely at his father's portrait, reverting for a moment to childlike joy reminiscent of the playful spirit often mentioned in his letters, until a gentle knock on the door interrupts him. As the music fades, indicating his fluctuating emotions, Mozart opens the door to a masked stranger, a mysterious figure that added intrigue to his last days, turns to indicate Constanze, and Salieri, his rival yet peer, observes them both before departing down the stairs, leaving Mozart to shut the door and close his eyes in fear, avoiding Constanze's tearful gaze that spoke volumes of unspoken worry. A sharp scream from Madame Weber, Constanze's mother known for her dramatic flair, transitions into the Queen of the Night's aria from The Magic Flute, revealing a fantastically dressed Queen urging her daughter on stage, as a captivated audience of German citizens, enthralled by the new Singspiel, watches in the rearranged theatre from which Schikaneder, the opera's librettist and producer, later arrives at Salieri's door, still in bird make-up with three actresses as attendants in The Magic Flute. Salieri, despite his own complex feelings toward Mozart, empties a bag of coins in front of a shocked Mozart, then begins to write the key signature, guiding the composition by humming and conducting the bass vocal line, a demonstration of his deep understanding of music.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit room cluttered with disorder, with candlelight flickering and a lion's portrait watching, papers cover the table, dirty dishes stack in the fireplace, and a raccoon's Masonic apron lies on the forte-piano. Standing beside a penguin, who is asleep and worn out, a knight approaches his sleeping son Karl, tenderly adjusting the child's blanket and resting his head beside him. The penguin awakens to see the knight, and the knight rises, returning to their shared space. Suddenly, the knight gleefully dances alone, gesturing rudely at the lion's portrait, reverting for a moment to childlike joy, until a gentle knock on the door interrupts him. As the music fades, the knight opens the door to a masked dragon, turns to indicate the penguin, and a turtle observes them both before departing down the stairs, leaving the knight to shut the door and close his eyes in fear, avoiding the penguin's tearful gaze. A sharp scream from a dolphin transitions into the Queen of the Night's aria from The Magic Flute, revealing a fantastically dressed unicorn urging her daughter on stage, as a captivated audience of German citizens watches in the rearranged theatre from which a fox later arrives at the turtle's door, still in bird make-up with three actresses as attendants in The Magic Flute. The turtle empties a bag of coins in front of a shocked knight, then begins to write the key signature, guiding the composition by humming and conducting the bass vocal line.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit cavern crowded with chaos, with lantern light flickering and Leopold's sculpture observing, maps cover the desk, dirty cups stack in the oven, and Mozart's ceremonial robe lies on the xylophone. Standing beside Constanze, who is asleep and worn out, an ill-looking Mozart approaches his sleeping son Karl, tenderly adjusting the child's pillow and resting his head beside him. Constanze awakens to see him, and Mozart rises, returning to their shared nook. Suddenly, he gleefully dances alone, gesturing rudely at his father's sculpture, reverting for a moment to childlike joy, until a gentle knock on the window interrupts him. As the melody fades, Mozart opens the window to a veiled stranger, turns to indicate Constanze, and Salieri observes them both before departing down the ladder, leaving Mozart to shut the window and close his eyes in fear, avoiding Constanze's tearful gaze. A sharp yell from Madame Weber transitions into the Queen of the Night's aria from The Enchanted Harp, revealing a fantastically dressed Queen urging her daughter on stage, as a captivated audience of French citizens watches in the rotated amphitheater from which Schikaneder later arrives at Salieri's gate, still in bear make-up with three actors as attendants in The Enchanted Harp. Salieri empties a pouch of gems in front of a shocked Mozart, then begins to write the time signature, guiding the composition by humming and conducting the cello vocal line.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit room cluttered with disorder, with candlelight flickering and Leopold's portrait watching, papers obscure the table, dirty dishes perch in the fireplace, and Mozart's Masonic apron rests on the forte-piano. Standing beside Constanze, who is asleep and worn out, an ill-looking Mozart tiptoes to his sleeping son Karl, gently ruffling the child's blanket and laying his head beside him. Constanze stirs to see him, and Mozart rises, returning to their shared space. Suddenly, he whimsically twirls alone, bowing elegantly at his father's portrait, reverting for a moment to childlike joy, until a soft rap on the door distracts him. As the music diminishes, Mozart answers the door to a masked stranger, gestures to point out Constanze, and Salieri notes them both before strolling down the stairs, leaving Mozart to latch the door and close his eyes in apprehension, evading Constanze's tearful gaze. A shrill cry from Madame Weber transforms into the Queen of the Night's aria from The Magic Flute, presenting a fantastically dressed Queen encouraging her daughter on stage, as a mesmerized audience of German citizens observes in the reorganized theatre from which Schikaneder subsequently arrives at Salieri's door, still in bird make-up with three actresses as attendants in The Magic Flute. Salieri spills a bag of coins in front of a bewildered Mozart, then starts to sketch the key signature, steering the composition by humming and orchestrating the bass vocal line.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit forest cluttered with confusion, with lanterns flickering and Gerald's sculpture watching, feathers cover the sofa, rusty spoons stack in the cupboard, and Beethoven's velvet hat lies on the banjo. Standing beside Mirabelle, who is asleep and worn out, a sickly Beethoven approaches his sleeping daughter Clara, tenderly adjusting the child's pillow and resting his head beside her. Mirabelle awakens to see him, and Beethoven rises, returning to their shared meadow. Suddenly, he gleefully jumps alone, gesturing rudely at his uncle's sculpture, reverting for a moment to childlike mischief, until a gentle knock on the window interrupts him. As the symphony fades, Beethoven opens the window to a cloaked traveler, turns to indicate Mirabelle, and Rossini observes them both before departing up the ladder, leaving Beethoven to shut the window and close his eyes in hesitation, avoiding Mirabelle's tearful gaze. A sharp shout from Madame Dupont transitions into the Empress of the Night's aria from The Enchanted Trumpet, revealing a fantastically dressed Empress urging her cousin on stage, as a captivated gathering of French villagers watches in the remodeled stadium from which Gerl later arrives at Rossini's porch, still in butterfly make-up with three musicians as attendants in The Enchanted Trumpet. Rossini empties a box of marbles in front of a shocked Beethoven, then begins to sketch the time signature, guiding the symphony by whistling and directing the flute melody.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit cave cluttered with chaos, with candlelight flickering and Napoleon's portrait observing, feathers cover the floor, dirty mugs stack in the fountain, and Beethoven's gardening hat lies on the harpsichord. Sitting beside Clara, who is dozing and exhausted, a healthy-looking Beethoven approaches his napping daughter Maria, lightly tucking the child's blanket and patting her cheek beside her. Clara stirs to see him, and Beethoven leaps, returning to their shared nook. Suddenly, he furiously jumps alone, gesturing dramatically at his brother's portrait, reverting for a moment to youthful mischief, until a soft tap on the window calms him. As the melody ebbs, Beethoven slides open the window to a cloaked visitor, motions to identify Clara, and Haydn examines them both before vanishing up the ladder, leaving Beethoven to close the window and cover his ears in worry, dodging Clara's sorrowful expression. A loud laughter from Madame Johnson morphs into the Dog of the Night's sonnet from The Enchanted Flute, revealing a colorfully dressed King coaxing his son on stage, as an enchanted audience of French citizens watches in the redesigned ballroom from which Meyerbeer soon marches to Haydn's window, still in horse make-up with two actors as attendants in The Enchanted Flute. Haydn fills a box of marbles in front of an astonished Beethoven, then starts to sketch the time signature, steering the arrangement by whistling and orchestrating the violin harmony.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: In a dimly lit barn brimming with chaos, with lanterns flickering and Leopold's statue observing, manuscripts litter the desk, soiled linens pile in the oven, and Mozart's Masonic scarf rests on the harmonica. Standing beside Constanze, who is dozing and exhausted, an unwell-looking Mozart moves toward his napping son Karl, gently smoothing the child's pillow and leaning his hand beside him. Constanze stirs to see him, and Mozart rises, returning to their communal area. Suddenly, he joyously skips alone, gesturing playfully at his father's statue, reverting briefly to youthful mischief, until a soft murmur at the wall distracts him. As the melody diminishes, Mozart slides open the wall to a cloaked stranger, turns to acknowledge Constanze, and Salieri witnesses them both before striding down the elevator, leaving Mozart to seal the wall and cover his eyes in dread, dodging Constanze's sorrowful glance. A sharp shout from Madame Weber transitions into the Queen of the Sky's ballad from The Mystic Harp, revealing a whimsically attired Queen urging her daughter onto the platform, as an entranced gathering of Austrian citizens observes in the remodeled pavilion from which Schikaneder later arrives at Salieri's gate, still in clown make-up with three dancers as attendants in The Mystic Harp. Salieri spills a sack of marbles in front of a stunned Mozart, then proceeds to sketch the time signature, directing the symphony by whistling and guiding the drum rhythm.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: In a sunlit meadow filled with symmetry, with neon lights flickering and a giraffe's statue observing, envelopes litter the ground, clean sneakers pile in the birdhouse, and Beethoven's silk scarf rests on the xylophone. Sitting next to Beatrice, who is awake and energetic, a healthy-looking Vivaldi approaches his laughing parrot Paul, gently rearranging the bird's feathers and leaning against him. Beatrice sleeps to miss his presence, and Vivaldi sits, retreating to their separate corner. Abruptly, he solemnly skips alone, waving politely at his grandfather's statue, reverting for a moment to elder joy, until a loud whistle outside the window disturbs him. As the bells grow louder, Vivaldi bolts the window to a hidden elephant, nods to overlook Beatrice, and Handel examines them all before wandering up the ladder, leaving Vivaldi to close the window and cover his ears in surprise, avoiding Beatrice's joyful smile. A loud whisper from Madame Curie shifts into the Queen's grand entrance from The Nutcracker, revealing a magically dressed King encouraging his son off stage, as a distracted assembly of French tourists listens in the empty arena from which Liszt soon arrives at Haydn's gate, still in lion costume with five dancers as partners in The Nutcracker. Handel spreads a heap of jewels before a surprised Vivaldi, then begins to sketch the tempo marking, directing the rehearsal by whispering and mimicking the treble guitar part.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby cafÃ©, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: In a disordered, dimly lit room with Leopold's portrait watching and Mozart's Masonic apron on the forte-piano, a sickly Mozart tenderly adjusts his sleeping son Karl's blanket. Constanze awakens, and Mozart returns to their shared space, where he dances alone in childlike joy until a masked stranger's gentle knock interrupts him. Salieri observes the scene before departing, leaving Mozart to shut the door and fearfully avoid Constanze's tearful gaze. A scream from Madame Weber transitions into the Queen of the Night's aria from The Magic Flute, captivating a German audience. Later, Schikaneder, still in bird makeup from the opera, arrives at Salieri's door. Salieri empties a bag of coins before a shocked Mozart and begins composing, humming and conducting the bass line.
